Celia.text: I will go anywhere with you, Mrs. Cadwallader,
I shall not look any more,

I dare say Dodo likes
it: she is fond of melancholy things and ugly people.
Why, Dodo, you never told me that Mr. Ladislaw was come again!
Now you can see him, Mrs. Cadwallader,

He is just like
a miniature of Mr. Casaubon's aunt that hangs in Dorothea's
boudoir—quite nice-looking.

MrsCad.text:
Oh, my dear, when you have a clergyman in your family you must
accommodate your tastes: I did that very early.  When I married
Humphrey I made up my mind to like sermons, and I set out by liking the
e
Quite right to feel obliged to me,

Your rich
Lowick farmers are as curious as any buffaloes or bisons, and I dare
say you don't half see them at church.  They are quite different from
your uncle's tenants or Sir James's—monsters—farmer

Think of that now! when so many younger sons can't dine at their own
expense,
Ah,

here is Mr. Brooke.  I felt that we were incomplete
before, and here is the explanation.  You are come to see this odd
funeral, of course?
Ah, now they are coming out of church,

Dear me, what a wonderfully mixed set!  Mr. Lydgate as doctor, I
suppose.  But that is really a good looking woman, and the fair young
man must be her son.  Who are they, Sir James, do you know?
Ah, yes: one of your secret committee,

And one of those who suck the life out of the wretched handloom
weavers in Tipton and Freshitt.  That is how his family look so fair
and sleek,

Those dark, purple-faced people
are an excellent foil.  Dear me, they are like a set of jugs!  Do look
at Humphrey: one might fancy him an ugly archangel towering above them
in his white surplice.

But I am not taking it in that light.  I can't wear my solemnity too
often, else it will go to rags.  It was time the old man died, and none
of these people are sorry.
Positively,

there is a new face come out
from behind that broad man queerer than any of them: a little round
head with bulging eyes—a sort of frog-face—do look.  He must be of
another blood, I think.
Who is Mr. Ladislaw?
A very pretty sprig,

What is your
nephew to be, Mr. Casaubon?
I understand,
One who can write speeches.
I know what you mean—the 'Pioneer' at the Grange!

It is frightful—this taking to buying whistles and blowing them in
everybody's hearing.  Lying in bed all day and playing at dominoes,
like poor Lord Plessy, would be more private and bearable.
I warned you all of it,

I said to Humphrey long ago, Mr. Brooke is going to make a
splash in the mud.  And now he has done it.
He may do that afterwards,

when he has come
out on the other side of the mud with an ague.
I know,

The independent member
hasn't got his speeches well enough by heart.
Oh, he's a dangerous young sprig, that Mr. Ladislaw,

with his opera songs and his ready tongue.  A sort of
Byronic hero—an amorous conspirator, it strikes me.  And Thomas
Aquinas is not fond of him.  I could see that, the day the picture was
brought.
It is Aquinas's fault,
Why didn't he use his interest to get Ladislaw made an attache or sent to India? That is how families get rid of troublesome sprigs.

There is one good chance—that he will not like to feel his money
oozing away,

If I knew the items of election
expenses I could scare him.  It's no use plying him with wide words
like Expenditure: I wouldn't talk of phlebotomy, I would empty a pot of
leeches upon him.  What we g
Come, that's a blessing,

That helps him to
find himself in a morning.  He may not know his own opinions, but he
does know his own pocket.

Oh, stinginess may be abused like other virtues: it will not do to
keep one's own pigs lean,

But talk of an independent politician and he will
appear.

Yes.  Now, you ply him with the 'Trumpet,' Humphrey; and I will put
the leeches on him.  What will you do, Sir James?

I thought the most expensive hobby in the world was standing for
Parliament,

They said the last unsuccessful
candidate at Middlemarch—Giles, wasn't his name?—spent ten thousand
pounds and failed because he did not bribe enough.  What a bitter
reflection for a man!
And that if you got pelted,

half the
rotten eggs would mean hatred of your committee-man. Good heavens!
Think what it must be to be pelted for wrong opinions.  And I seem to
remember a story of a man they pretended to chair and

And it is not martyrdom to pay bills that one has run into one's
self,
Excuse me, it is you two who are on the wrong tack,

You should have proved to him that he loses money by bad
management, and then we should all have pulled together.  If you put
him a-horseback on politics, I warn you of the consequences.  It was
all v

JC.text: Most of these followers are not Lowick people,

I
suppose they are legatees from a distance, or from Middlemarch.
Lovegood tells me the old fellow has left a good deal of money as well
as land.

I see Vincy, the Mayor of Middlemarch; they are probably his wife and
son,
A coursing fellow, though,
A young relative of Mr. Casaubon's,

Sir James Chettam could not look with any satisfaction on Mr. Brooke's
new courses; but it was easier to object than to hinder.

I can't talk to you as I want, before Celia: it might hurt her.
Indeed, it would not be right.
I do wish Brooke would leave that off,
Exactly,

I have been inquiring
into the thing, for I've never known anything about Middlemarch
politics before—the county being my business.  What Brooke trusts to,
is that they are going to turn out Oliver be
What I care for most is his own dignity,

Of course
I care the more because of the family.  But he's getting on in life
now, and I don't like to think of his exposing himself.  They will be
raking up everything against him.
Well, no,

I feel a delicacy in appearing to dictate.
But I have been talking to this young Ladislaw that Brooke is making a
factotum of.  Ladislaw seems clever enough for anything.  I thought it
as well to hear
But this Ladislaw—there again is a vexatious business,

We have had him two or three times to dine at the Hall (you
have met him, by the bye) as Brooke's guest and a relation of
Casaubon's, thinking he was only on a flying visit.  And now I find
he's in ev
There <emph rend="italics">is</emph> some foreign blood in Ladislaw,

I
hope he won't go into extreme opinions and carry Brooke on.
I don't like to begin on the subject with Casaubon,

He has more right to interfere than I. But it's a disagreeable affair
all round.  What a character for anybody with decent connections to
show himself in!—one of those newspaper fellows!  You have onl

Exactly: that makes it so annoying that Brooke should have put a man
who has a sort of connection with the family in a position of that
kind.  For my part, I think Ladislaw is rather a fool for accept
There is no knowing to what lengths the mischief may go,
But if Casaubon says nothing, what can I do?
And he will not like having things raked up against him,

There is the management of his estate.  They have begun upon
that already.  And it really is painful for me to see.  It is a
nuisance under one's very nose.  I do think one is bound to do the best
for

I want him to have a proper man to look after things—I want him to
take on Garth again,

He got rid of Garth twelve
years ago, and everything has been going wrong since.  I think of
getting Garth to manage for me—he has made such a capital plan for my
buildings; and Lovegood is hardly up

If Dorothea had kept near her uncle, there would have been some
chance,

She might have got some power over him in
time, and she was always uneasy about the estate.  She had wonderfully
good notions about such things.  But now Casaubon takes her up
entirely.  Celia complai
In point of fact,

Brooke doesn't mean badly by his tenants or any one else, but he has
got that way of paring and clipping at expenses.
I don't believe a man is in pocket by stinginess on his land,

The fact is, I don't like to begin about it with Brooke, in our mutual
position; the whole thing is so unpleasant.  I do wish people would
behave like gentlemen,
Well, that is really a hit about the gates,

Dagley complained to me the other day that he
hadn't got a decent gate on his farm.  Garth has invented a new pattern
of gate—I wish you would try it.  One ought to use some of one's
timber in that wa
Hawley says you have men on your side who will do you harm,
He says Bulstrode the banker will do you harm.
The fact is,

if a man goes into public life he must
be prepared for the consequences.  He must make himself proof against
calumny.
Exactly,

What I
mean by being proof against calumny is being able to point to the fact
as a contradiction.
Well, you know, Chettam,

you and I have a different system.  You are all
for outlay with your farms.  I don't want to make out that my system is
good under all circumstances—under all circumstances, you know.
There ought to be a new valuation made from time to time,

Returns are very well occasionally, but I like a fair
valuation.  What do you say, Cadwallader?
I didn't want to take a liberty with Brooke,

I see
he is nettled.  But as to what he says about old tenants, in point of
fact no new tenant would take the farms on the present terms.

MB.text:
No, I came to look after Casaubon—to see how he goes on, you know.
And to bring a little news—a little news, my dear,

I looked into the
library, and I saw Casaubon over his books.  I told him it wouldn't do:
I said, 'This will never do, you know: think of your wife, Casaubon.'
And he promised me to come up.  I didn't

Yes, a very decent family—a very good fellow is Vincy; a credit to
the manufacturing interest.  You have seen him at my house, you know.
It's a solemn thing, though, a funeral,

if you take
it in that light, you know.

He came with me, you know; he is my guest—puts up with me at the
Grange,

And we
have brought the picture at the top of the carriage.  I knew you would

A very nice young fellow—Casaubon has done everything for him,
He repays your expense in him, Casaubon,

I hope he will stay with me a long
while and we shall make something of my documents.  I have plenty of
ideas and facts, you know, and I can see he is just the man to put them
into shape—remembers wha
Well, you know,

he is trying his wings.  He
is just the sort of young fellow to rise.  I should be glad to give him
an opportunity.  He would make a good secretary, now, like Hobbes,
Milton, Swift—that sort of man.
I'll fetch him in now, eh, Casaubon?

He wouldn't
come in till I had announced him, you know.  And we'll go down and look

mean as to anything objectionable—laxities or atheism, or anything of

Never
fear, Casaubon!  Depend upon it, young Ladislaw will do you credit.
Depend upon it, I have put my finger on the right thing.
Here you all are, eh?

Eh? no,

Oh, that is Keck—an illiterate fellow, you know.  Retrogressive, now!
Come, that's capital.  He thinks it means destructive: they want to
make me out a destructive, you know,
Come, that's rather good, you know,

that about roaring himself red
at rotten boroughs—I never made a speech about rotten boroughs in my

You go in for fancy farming, you know, Chettam,

That's your

Nothing of the kind,

The Tories bribe, you know:
Hawley and his set bribe with treating, hot codlings, and that sort of

My dear Chettam, that is all very fine, you know,

But it was Sir James's evident annoyance that most stirred Mr. Brooke.

But

Well, my dear, this is pleasant, now,

You have left Casaubon with his books, I suppose.
That's right.  We must not have you getting too learned for a woman,

Why, yes, my dear, it was quite your hobby to draw plans.  But it was

Chettam is a little hasty, my dear,

a little hasty, you know.  I never said I should do anything

he finds fault with me, my dear; but I

Well, well, I'll speak to
your wife—I didn't mean beating, you know,
How do you do, Mrs. Dagley?

I
came to tell you about your boy: I don't want you to give him the

My good fellow, you're drunk, you know,
Another day, another day,

D.text: How piteous!

This funeral seems to me the most
dismal thing I ever saw.  It is a blot on the morning. I cannot bear to
think that any one should die and leave no love behind.

Poor Dorothea felt that every word of her uncle's was about as pleasant
as a grain of sand in the eye to Mr. Casaubon.  It would be altogether
unfitting now to explain that she had not wished her uncl

But Will Ladislaw always seemed to see more in what she said than she
herself saw. Dorothea had little vanity, but she had the ardent
woman's need to rule beneficently by making the joy of another sou
Mr. Casaubon has gone to the Archdeacon's,

I
don't know whether he will be at home again long before dinner.  He was
uncertain how long he should be.  Did you want to say anything
particular to him?
Yes,
Sit down.

Dorothea for the moment forgot her
husband's mysterious irritation against Will: it seemed fresh water at
her thirsty lips to speak without fear to the one person whom she had
found receptive; for in
I have often thought that I should like to talk to you again,

It seems strange to me how many things I said to
you.
I have tried to learn a great deal since we were in Rome,

I can read Latin a little, and I am beginning to understand
just a little Greek.  I can help Mr. Casaubon better now.  I can find
out references for him and save his eyes in many ways.  But it is very
You correct me,

I expressed myself ill.  I should
have said that those who have great thoughts get too much worn in
working them out.  I used to feel about that, even when I was a little
girl; and it always seemed to
How can you think of that?

I should have no happiness if I did not help him in his
work.  What could I do?  There is no good to be done in Lowick.  The
only thing I desire is to help him more.  And he objects to a
secretary: pl
Yes,

but they don't understand—they want me to be a
great deal on horseback, and have the garden altered and new
conservatories, to fill up my days.  I thought you could understand
that one's mind has othe
besides, Mr. Casaubon cannot bear to hear of a secretary.

You were not a
steady worker enough.

She was no
longer struggling against the perception of facts, but adjusting
herself to their clearest perception; and now when she looked steadily
at her husband's failure, still more at his possible

Mr. Casaubon must have overcome his
dislike of you so far as his actions were concerned: and that is
admirable.
I wish I knew all about her!

I wonder how she bore
the change from wealth to poverty: I wonder whether she was happy with
her husband!  Do you know much about them?
Ah, what a different life from mine!

I have always had too much
of everything.  But tell me how it was—Mr. Casaubon could not have
known about you then.
No,

Mr. Casaubon has always avoided dwelling on
his own honorable actions.

He had never told me that he
supported your mother.  Is she still living?

That is your
apology, I suppose, for having yourself been rather rebellious; I mean,
to Mr. Casaubon's wishes.  You must remember that you have not done
what he thought best for you.  And if he dislik

my uncle has not told you
how serious Mr. Casaubon's illness was.  It would be very petty of us
who are well and can bear things, to think much of small offences from
those who carry a weight of trial
That is very good of you,

I
shall have a little kingdom then, where I shall give laws.  But you
will soon go away, out of my rule, I imagine.  You will soon be tired
of staying at the Grange.
Would not that be a sacrifice of higher prospects for you?
I should like you to stay very much,

There was not the shadow
of a reason in her mind at the moment why she should not say so.

But my opinion is of little consequence on such a subject.  I think
you should be guided by Mr. Casaubon.  I spoke without thinking of
anything else than my own feeling, which has nothing to do with t
I wish you could have stayed,

She also had her
thought which she did not like to express:—Will certainly ought to
lose no time in consulting Mr. Casaubon's wishes, but for her to urge
this might seem an undue dictation.
I am very glad you have had that pleasure,

Before you
came I had been regretting that you happened to be out to-day.

Because Mr. Ladislaw has been here; and he has mentioned a proposal of
my uncle's which I should like to know your opinion of.

Her husband
she felt was really concerned in this question.  Even with her

What is your opinion?
No,

he did not say that he came to ask
your opinion.  But when he mentioned the proposal, he of course
expected me to tell you of it.

I feared that you might feel some objection.  But certainly a young
man with so much talent might be very useful to my uncle—might help
him to do good in a better way.  And Mr. Ladislaw wishes to have

Dorothea felt that this was a consideration to soften her husband.

and the Archdeacon's breakfast.  But there was no longer sunshi

And now, since her conversation with Will, many fresh images had
gathered round that Aunt Julia who was Will's grandmother; the presence

It was true, she said to herself, that Mr. Casaubon had a debt to the
Ladislaws—that he had to pay back what the Ladislaws had been wronged
of.  And now she began to think of her husband's will, which
But he will!

The
great strength of his character lies here.  And what are we doing with
our money?  We make no use of half of our income.  My own money buys me
nothing but an uneasy conscience.
Do you feel ill, dear?
May I talk to you a little instead?

I have been thinking about money all day—that I have always had too
much, and especially the prospect of too much.

But if one has too much in consequence of others being wronged, it
seems to me that the divine voice which tells us to set that wrong
right must be obeyed.

That you have been too liberal in arrangements for me—I mean, with
regard to property; and that makes me unhappy.

I have been led to think about your aunt Julia, and how she was left
in poverty only because she married a poor man, an act which was not
disgraceful, since he was not unworthy.  It was on that ground

But surely we should regard his claim as a much greater one, even to

And I think he ought at once to be provided for on that under
Indeed, no!

How can you imagine it, since
he has so lately declined everything from you?  I fear you think too
hardly of him, dear.  He only told me a little about his parents and
grandparents, and almost all in
There is no fear of that, uncle,

I am very slow.  When I
want to be busy with books, I am often playing truant among my
thoughts.  I find it is not so easy to be learned as to plan cottages.
Yes,

Sir James has
been telling me that he is in hope of seeing a great change made soon

If I were at home
still, I should take to riding again, that I might go about with you

He only feels confident that you will do it,

because you mean to enter Parliament as a member who cares for

No, I did not,
I am very, very sorry,

since you and Mr. Casaubon
disagree.  You intend to remain?
No,

hardly ever.  But
I shall hear of you.  I shall know what you are doing for my uncle.

No one will tell
me anything.
Oh, my life is very simple,

I am always at
Lowick.
No, don't think that,
I have no longings.
He did not speak, but she replied to some change in his expression.

I
mean, for myself.  Except that I should like not to have so much more

of my own, and it comforts me.

That by desiring what is perfectly good, even when we don't quite know

You will say it is Persian, or something else

What is <emph rend="italics">your</emph> religion?

I mean—not what you know
about religion, but the belief that helps you most?
But if you like what is good, that comes to the same thing,

Yes; Mr. Casaubon often says I am too subtle.  I don't feel as if I
were subtle,

But how long my uncle is!  I
must go and look for him.  I must really go on to the Hall.  Celia is
expecting me.
That was very brutal, I think,

Dorothea withdrew her arm and lingered on
the matting, that she might leave her husband quite free.

What have I done—what am I—that he should treat me so?  He never
knows what is in my mind—he never cares.  What is the use of anything
I do?  He wishes he had never married me.
Is he worth living for?

It is
his fault, not mine.

In the jar of her whole being, Pity was
overthrown.  Was it her fault that she had believed in him—had
believed in his worthiness?—And what, exactly, was he?—  She was able

I shall not dine, then, Tantripp.

No; I am not well.  Get everything ready in my dressing room, but pray

Yes, I did not like to disturb you.

C.text:
You are exceedingly hospitable, my dear sir; and I owe you
acknowledgments for exercising your hospitality towards a relative of
mine.
Pardon me, he is not my nephew.  He is my cousin.

His antipathy to Will did
not spring from the common jealousy of a winter-worn husband: it was

MrV.text:

Eh Standish?

Well, sir,

Good-by,

like the outside world better.  It is a very inconvenient fault of

Yes, father: the school at York.  I have determined to take it.  It is

descriptions.D: #MrsCad">Ah, yes: one of your secret committee, said Mrs. Cadwallader, provokingly. A coursing fellow, though, said Sir James, with a fox-hunter's disgust. And one of those who suck the life out of the wretched handloom weavers in Tipton and Freshitt. That is how his family look so fair and sleek, said Mrs. Cadwallader. Those dark, purple-faced people are an excellent foil. Dear me, they are like a set of jugs! Do look at Humphrey: one might fancy him an ugly archangel towering above them in his
descriptions.Celia: sk a favor instead of preaching. Moreover, he was one of the high gentry living four miles away from Lowick, and was thus exalted to an equal sky with the sheriff of the county and other dignities vaguely regarded as necessary to the system of things. There would be a satisfaction in being buried by Mr. Cadwallader, whose very name offered a fine opportunity for pronouncing wrongly if you liked. This distinction conferred on the Rector of Tipton and Freshitt was the reason why Mrs. Cadwallader m
descriptions.B: to you, Harriet, before you married Bulstrode, and I must say he doesn't always show that friendly spirit towards your family that might have been expected of him. Mr. Vincy was very little like a Jesuit, but no accomplished Jesuit could have turned a question more adroitly. Harriet had to defend her husband instead of blaming her brother, and the conversation ended at a point as far from the beginning as some recent sparring between the brothers-in-law at a vestry meeting. I am sure we are bound to pray for that thoughtless girl—brought up as she has been, said Mrs. Bulstrode, wishing to rouse her husband's feelings. Truly, my dear, said Mr. Bulstrode, assentingly. Those who are not of this world can do little else to arrest the errors of the obstinately worldly. That is what we must accustom ourselves to recognize with regard to your brother's family. I could have wished that Mr. Lydgate had not entere
descriptions.Lad: we have grave reasons for objecting to) is likely to have a secret contempt for us, and any one who admires him passes an oblique criticism on ourselves. Having the scruples of rectitude in our souls, we are above the meanness of injuring him—rather we meet all his claims on us by active benefits; and the drawing of cheques for him, being a superiority which he must recognize, gives our bitterness a milder infusion. Now Mr. Casaubon had been deprived of that superiority (as anything more than a
descriptions.R: > Please the deuce! said Mr. Vincy. Bulstrode won't pay for their keep. And if Lydgate thinks I'm going to give money for them to set up housekeeping, he's mistaken, that's all. I expect I shall have to put down my horses soon. You'd better tell Rosy what I say. This was a not infrequent procedure with Mr. Vincy—to be rash in jovial assent, and on becoming subsequently conscious that he had been rash, to employ others in making the offensive retractation. However, Mrs. Vincy, who never willingly
descriptions.M: d had his pleasure in ruminating on it. And certainly Mr. Standish was surprised, but not at all sorry; on the contrary, he rather enjoyed the zest of a little curiosity in his own mind, which the discovery of a second will added to the prospective amazement on the part of the Featherstone family. As to the sentiments of Solomon and Jonah, they were held in utter suspense: it seemed to them that the old will would have a certain validity, and that there might be such an interlacement of poor Pet
descriptions.F: thought about everybody: it looks well when a man wants to be followed by his friends, and if they are humble, not to be ashamed of them. I should be all the better pleased if he'd left lots of small legacies. They may be uncommonly useful to fellows in a small way. Everything is as handsome as could be, crape and silk and everything, said Mrs. Vincy, contentedly. But I am sorry to say that Fred was under some difficulty in repressing a laugh, which would have been more unsuitable than his fathe
descriptions.C: the house, you know, and she asked me to write. Poor Dorothea felt that every word of her uncle's was about as pleasant as a grain of sand in the eye to Mr. Casaubon. It would be altogether unfitting now to explain that she had not wished her uncle to invite Will Ladislaw. She could not in the least make clear to herself the reasons for her husband's dislike to his presence—a dislike painfully impressed on her by the scene in the library; but she felt the unbecomingness of saying anything that m
descriptions.MB: to feel obliged to me, said Mrs. Cadwallader. Your rich Lowick farmers are as curious as any buffaloes or bisons, and I dare say you don't half see them at church. They are quite different from your uncle's tenants or Sir James's—monsters—farmers without landlords—one can't tell how to class them. Most of these followers are not Lowick people, said Sir James; I suppose they are legatees from a distance, or from Middlemarch. Lovegood tells me the old fellow has left a good deal of money as well a
descriptions.JC: that she could slyly touch his coat with her cheek. I dare say Dodo likes it: she is fond of melancholy things and ugly people. I am fond of knowing something about the people I live among, said Dorothea, who had been watching everything with the interest of a monk on his holiday tour. It seems to me we know nothing of our neighbors, unless they are cottagers. One is constantly wondering what sort of lives other people lead, and how they take things. descriptions.LC: s distinction conferred on the Rector of Tipton and Freshitt was the reason why Mrs. Cadwallader made one of the group that watched old Featherstone's funeral from an upper window of the manor. She was not fond of visiting that house, but she liked, as she said, to see collections of strange animals such as there would be at this funeral; and she had persuaded Sir James and the young Lady Chettam to drive the Rector and herself to Lowick in order that the visit might be altogether pleasant. descriptions.MrsV: here, is but nineteen—so I leave you to guess. And stock always short, and land most awkward. But if ever I've begged and prayed; it's been to God above; though where there's one brother a bachelor and the other childless after twice marrying—anybody might think! Meanwhile, Mr. Vincy had glanced at the passive face of Mr. Rigg, and had taken out his snuff-box and tapped it, but had put it again unopened as an indulgence which, however clarifying to the judgment, was unsuited to the occasion. I never was covetous, Jane, she replied; but I have six children and have buried three, and I didn't marry into money. The eldest, that sits there, is but nineteen—so I leave you to guess. There would be a satisfaction in being buried by Mr. Cadwallader, whose very name offered a fine opportunity for pronouncing wrongly if you liked. descriptions.MrF: " direct="false" aloud="false"> He had even desired that female relatives should follow him to the grave, and poor sister Martha had taken a difficult journey for this purpose from the Chalky Flats. She and Jane would have been altogether cheered (in a tearful manner) by this sign that a brother who disliked seeing them while he was living had been prospectively fond of their presence when he should have become a testator, if the sign had not been made equivocal by being extended to Mrs. Vincy,
